bibl.title: Letter from John E. Worden, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, August 22, 1951

div1.p: Worden informs Hench the photographs will be used in connection with a plan by the Army to honor Walter Reed on the upcoming centennial of his birth. He adds that "The Washington Post" is preparing an article, and hopes that Hench will consider contributing to it.

div1.head: Letter from John E. Worden, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, August 22, 1951
div1.opener:
MEDEC -B
ARMY MEDICAL CENTER
WASHINGTON 12, D. C.
August 22, 1951
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you for your letter about the availability of
Walter Reed photographs. We have succeeded in obtain-
ing a number from the Army Medical Museum as you sug-
gested, and we have written the Metropolitan Life In-
surance Company. We have also located in the meantime
a sufficient number of copies of the very fine article
you did for Hygeia, “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”.

The Department of Army has at this moment a general plan
under consideration to honor Major Walter Reed on September
13. As soon as the details are available, I would appre-
ciate the privilege of sending this plan to you for your
information and any comments that you might have.

The Washington Post is planning on using a full page of
Dean Cromwell's painting “Conquerors of Yellow Fever” in
color, together with a lengthy article. They asked for
your address in hopes that you might desire to contribute
something to this article.
Thank you very much for your assistance, Doctor.

closer.signed:
JOHN E. WORDEN, JR.
Public Information Officer
